TO « Officers, Directors and Members, Membership Committee
FROM : John W. Dunn, Chairman, Membership Committee Sept. 22, 1952
So far, Pve received only three reactions from officers and board members and two
reactions from the Membership Committee regarding my memos of Sept. 10 & 11 which
had to do with some very pressing problems concerning membership in NAEB.
Now several of you are concerned over the TV lads and how we shall handle them in
NAEB. Article IX of the By-Laws of NAEB clearly states among other things: "Radio
Broadcasting, TELEVISION and Facsimile are included in the term BROADCASTING as used
within these By-Laws". Therefore, we can legitimately include television not only
in the title of our association but also in the basic overall concept of NAEB.
Although we need no general overhauling of the constitution and by-laws to bring
educational TV stations into the fold, there are some notable changes which ought to
be made —* both in the Constitution and the By-Laws — so as to be consistent with
the spirit and intent of both the Preamble to the Constitution and Article IX.
(1) ARTICLE I (A) of the Constitution of NAEB should be amended to read as
follows: “Any university, college, school or public service agency of rec¬
ognized standing engaged in educational, non-commercial broadcasting over a
radio station AND/OR A TELEVISION STATION controlled by it or holding a construc¬
tion permit for EITHER A RADIO OR TELEVISION STATION may be elected to member¬
ship by the Board of Directors.
The caps are the changes I propose making. To this article I would add:
PROVIDED, HOWEVER, THAT ANI SUCH UNIVERSITY, COLLEGE, SCHOOL OR PUBLIC SERVICE
AGENCY SO ELECTED TO MEMBERSHIP ON THE BASIS OF A CONSTRUCTION PERMIT AND WHO
ALLOWS THAT CONSTRUCTION PERMIT TO LAPSE OR IS DENIED RENEWAL BY THE FEDERAL
COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION SHALL AUTOMATICALLY REVERT TO ASSOCIATE MEMBERSHIP.
(2) Nothing needs to be done to ARTICLE I (B) so far as television is concerned
since by definition in Article IX of the By-Laws broadcasting includes Television.
However, I am in favor of striking out the word, “INDIVIDUAL" to be found in
Article I (B) and setting up another classification, I (C) to read as follows:
(C) The Board of Directors of the NAEB may, by unanimous consent, extend
INDIVIDUAL MEMBERSHIP to those persons (l) who have rendered outstanding
service to the association over a period of years as a representative of
either an Active or Associate member of the association in good standing;
(2) who shall have made a distinct contribution to the cause of educational
broadcasting in America.
(3) In the By-Laws of the Association, Article III, Section 1 a, ACTIVE DEFINI¬
TION should have the following changes, ".....engaged in educational, non¬
commercial broadcasting over a radio station AND/OR TELEVISION STATION, shall
be, etc., etc....11 The caps are the changes I propose making.

needs no change to include Television. Here again I am in favor of striking
